content: The final step of a Lean3 proof requires me to show that: a % (a + b) \= 0 when gcd a b = 1. Should be simple enough, but I just can't find a way of doing it. Any suggestions?
example (a b : ℤ) (p : ℕ) (h1 : is_coprime a b) : a^p % (a + b) ≠ 0 :=

Even your first statement needs some more assumptions surely, if a and b are any pair of integers summing to one then a % (a + b) = 0, even if the two values are coprime (which they surely are as they sum to one)

That said, probably you want to get that gcd a (a+b) = gcd a b = 1 from your assumption (probably by simpa), then rw with docs#int.dvd_iff_mod_eq_zero then change to the statement that a + b | a which should be true if and only if gcd a (a + b) = a + b (docs#gcd_eq_right_iff), which should show that the only exceptions are when a + b equals plus or minus one, I guess in your actual proof you have some reason this cant be so
Thanks, guys. (a + b) cannot equal +/-1 in the proof, but I had forgotten that Lean includes zero in the natural numbers. Haven't quite fixed it yet, but making progress again.
